intro: Leptochloris greggii, commonly known as Gregg's ghostflower, is a rare and delicate flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its small, white to pale blue flowers. The plant has finely divided, fern-like leaves and is often found in rocky, arid environments. It is adapted to thrive in dry, well-drained soils and is known for its subtle, almost ghostly appearance. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
